channel.title: The Christian Science Monitor | USA
channel.description: US national news from The Christian Science Monitor.
channel.copyright: Christian Science Monitor. All rights reserved.

item.title: How Biden and Trump compare on border crossings and immigration
item.description: Immigration is a top campaign issue amid questions about the pace of illegal border crossings. Here’s what the available data tells us.
item.dc:creator: Christa Case Bryant
Caitlin Babcock

item.title: In words and deeds, US seeks Israeli restraint after Iran’s attack
item.description: With a muscular and collaborative defensive effort to help deflect Iran’s missile barrage, the Biden administration is hoping its message of “ironclad support” for Israel can prevent the escalation of the Gaza war into a regional conflict.
item.dc:creator: Howard LaFranchi

item.title: Why Trump criminal trial is about more than hush money
item.description: The so-called hush money case has been billed as one of the less important lawsuits facing former President Donald Trump. But it’s the one underway.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grier
Sophie Hills

item.title: As money moves digital, Denver Mint still coins a pretty penny
item.description: At Denver’s Mint, the legacy of money and its future are on display. In an era of online payments, experts weigh coin costs against virtual options.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Matusek

item.title: Two states warn that Biden may be kept off their ballots
item.description: The Democratic convention won’t nominate Joe Biden until after ballot access deadlines in Ohio and Alabama have passed. In similar cases, states have accommodated major candidates.
item.dc:creator: Story Hinckley

item.title: How America lost trust in elections – and why that matters
item.description: Doubts about election integrity go way back. They were amplified by the court-decided election of 2000, then supercharged by Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grier

item.title: They couldn’t drive back home. US driving schools help refugee women.
item.description: Women from countries that ban female driving have found newfound freedom in America. Driving schools in Georgia are giving lessons to recent immigrants and refugees looking to build a new life, with freedom front of mind.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Johnson

item.title: Pregnant Black women feel lost in the medical system. Doulas offer guidance – and a voice.
item.description: As Black expectant mothers try to navigate a medical system in which they have little confidence, Black doulas have become trusted members of their pregnancy teams.
item.dc:creator: Cameron Pugh

item.title: In Arizona and beyond, an abortion uproar has Republicans scrambling
item.description: Leaving abortion to states increases the stakes for the 2024 election – and roils Republicans over how to respond.
item.dc:creator: Linda Feldmann

item.title: Could MAGA candidates in key swing states drag down Trump?
item.description: MAGA Republicans running for Senate and governor are trailing their Democratic opponents, even as former President Donald Trump leads President Joe Biden.
item.dc:creator: Story Hinckley

item.title: Bryan Stevenson Q&A: Alabama park confronts difficult history in sculpture
item.description: In Montgomery, Alabama, a new sculpture park has joined two memorials created by the Equal Justice Initiative started by Bryan Stevenson, a lawyer perhaps best known for his memoir, “Just Mercy.”
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie McCarty

item.title: Part-time student, full-time congressman. Rep. Don Beyer is learning AI.
item.description: AI technology is a rising focus of legislation in Congress. Rep. Don Beyer is heading back to college for a master's in machine learning, hoping to stay informed ahead of legislative debates.
item.dc:creator: David Klepper

item.title: Biden and Japan’s Kishida bolster defense ties to counter China
item.description: Amid tension with China over the future of Taiwan, part of U.S. strategy is a major upgrade of security ties with Japan.
item.dc:creator: Anna Mulrine Grobe

item.title: With antisemitism on rise, Auschwitz exhibit counters with proof of Holocaust
item.description: Amid the Israel-Hamas war, antisemitism and Holocaust denial have risen. An Auschwitz exhibit stands firmly for the truth by providing evidence of atrocities – and humanity.
item.dc:creator: Leonardo Bevilacqua

item.title: Parents of Michigan school shooter sentenced. They ignored warning signs, judge says
item.description: A Michigan couple was sentenced to at least 10 years in prison for their teenage son’s murder of four fellow students. It was the first time parents have been held criminally liable for a mass shooting committed by their child.
item.dc:creator: Ed White

item.title: Arizona court revives a 160-year-old law to ban virtually all abortions
item.description: The Arizona Supreme Court upheld an long-dormant law that bans nearly all abortions. The battleground state may see a ballot initiative to enshrine abortion rights in its constitution come November.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Pierson and Nate Raymond

item.title: Food companies reverse their pandemic strategies as consumer spending plummets
item.description: Low-income Americans are cutting household spending on fast food and groceries. Big food companies like Kraft Heinz are offering more deals and options – a reversal from pandemic-era strategies to justify climbing prices.
item.dc:creator: Jessica DiNapoli

item.title: Biden woos Wisconsin voters with new student loan relief plan
item.description: President Joe Biden rallied voters in Wisconsin as he promoted a new student loan relief plan that would ease debt for more than 30 million borrowers. The new plan is scaled down after the Supreme Court struck down his initial plan last year.
item.dc:creator: Darlene Superville and Collin Binkley

item.title: Free trade or flooding the market? US warns China against surplus exports.
item.description: China and the U.S. share a desire to stabilize relations, but a recent trip by the U.S. treasury secretary highlights trade challenges.
item.dc:creator: Ann Scott Tyson

item.title: How Spanish-language media is fighting for truth this election season
item.description: Latino voters could be a major target for misinformation ahead of the 2024 elections. Combating it means an all-hands-on-deck effort.
item.dc:creator: Christine Fernando and Anita Snow
